comments.commentBody:
"It's horrifying that we have to fight our own government to save the environment." Ansel Adams

Truer words were never spoken.

The EPA is desperately in need of reform, and who better to implement those reforms than one who has had to fight against its arbitrary rule making. Obama has repeatedly exceeded his legal authority over the past several years, and he will soon see that yesterday's tyrant can quickly have his proclamations overturned by today's tyrant. Coal rules, mileage requirements, pipeline decisions, and the Paris accord were all implemented by a lawless president. Let's hope that Trump will reverse them all quickly.

The social benefits of the changes brought about through the EPA have been huge.  The undisputed improvements in air, water and waste management quality have benefitted all US citizens; however the uber rich see an opportunity to make more money by turning the clock back and keeping those corporate profits which are lost by conducting business in an ethical manner.  This is not a remotely surprising decision for a person who has always conducted his business for profit rather than ethics.  Sad for the rest of us who value the environment.

The environmental agenda is far broader than climate change matters. Pruitt has spoken out on climate change and is your typical anti-regulation Republican. Unfortunately, the media has targeted Pruitt's climate change views as today's headline, a sign that environmental matters have been pretty much reduced to climate change, which is a travesty.

The key problem with Pruitt's nomination is that he's unqualified to administer the EPA. That agency is responsible for dozens of environmental matters. Pruitt is the former Attorney General of Oklahoma. He prosecuted civil and criminal cases. I do not believe he ever brought a single action against the EPA. He joined some other Republican AG's in a couple of relevant cases, gave an interview to the National Review that addressed climate change and a couple of related matters. That's about it. He probably knows nothing or next to nothing about environmental science, or the environment itself. The big story isn't the few statements he's made. It's the lack of knowledge on his part. If he is approved, his only relevant view is that fewer regulations are better than more. Administering an agency with an eraser, but no pencil, is rank incompetence. James Watt, widely considered the worst of EPA's administrators, had a substantial background in environmental matters. Pruitt basically has none. The Senate should flush this guy down the toilet and require Trump to nominate someone who can distinguish clean water and vodka.

I'm old enough to remember the smog air inversions over Los Angeles in the 1960's and 70's and just, today, see that recently 10,000 Snow Geese died in an acid pit left over from an mining operation in Montana. I, like most Americans have been favored by recent lower energy costs (even under current regulations) despite that, since most recent EPA regulations have been by executive or agency action (with broad consensus never really established), I still fear there might be a reactionary swing, with a similar singularity of authority, in the other direction thus risking the environment.  Just another sad example of how pent up anger and misunderstanding results when a government (its branches and agencies) have a dysfunctional relationship.

By the logic Trump is showing with Pruitt's choice, we should put lead back in gasoline and paint, so that the unemployed lead miners can stop suffering from over-regulation. I'm being sarcastic because clean air and clean water are important, it makes no sense to put someone in charge of the EPA who doesn't hold to any of its values. It is one thing to argue against global warming, it is another to simply trash the environment.

With each announcement about Trump’s vile “nominations,” you continue to miss the point. You appear to think there’s a chance of the lapdog Congress rejecting any of these appointments.
The important thing about the persons selected by Trump to “lead” Environmental Protection, Schools, Health, Housing, and so on, is simply that each has a record of public pronouncements in direct opposition to the legally-mandated mission of the federal agency they will “lead.” Obviously their assignment will be to hobble, to financially gut, and if possible to simply close these agencies. These early announcements are intended to help create a fait accompli in two ways: first, by signaling to the middle management of these agencies – the ones that actually get work done - that it is time to get out while they still have the option; and second, by generating shock and awe among anyone who still thinks they might politically oppose the rape of the United States government. The fantasy that individual Americans can be legally protected from vicious economic predators – the Trumps of the world – is supposed to be surrendered for good.
Meanwhile I hear you struggling to maintain a civilized tone, to avoid giving Fox News any ammunition about perceived “bias,” and to continue the pretense of business as usual. The last President who took office on a specific platform of dismantling federal authority was James Buchanan, and the immediate result was the Civil War.

We have a wealth of energy resources in the USA. Most of them will remain that, resources, buried forever under the current EPA.

We'll perish economically before we will environmentally. The EPA is the poster child for government overreach in our businesses and in our lives.

This is a good appointment.

The EPA needs to be re-structured.  Most of its decisions have been based on either flawed or incomplete science.  It's become a rats' nest of activists pushing a radical agenda.  Pruitt is the antidote.

Just more liberal propaganda. The choice of Pruitt isn't about "healthy air and drinkable water". It's mainly about the EPA becoming an unchecked monster devoted to inhibiting the growth of the American economy. The article even acknowledges this saying Obama's Clean Power Plan " the plan could transform the electricity sector, close down hundreds of coal-fired power plants." Here's a newsflash - It is NOT within the EPA's purview to transform the electricity sector ! And many people's livelihoods depend on those coal-fired power plans and the energy it supplies. In fact, Hillary lost in every state that is either a major coal producer or uses coal for a significant portion of its power.

Look at California as the eptiome of the liberal vision. They already have a law in place to source 33% of their power from renewable sources by 2020. Keep in mind that the cost of coal is $87 / Mwh vs solar at between $98 and $174 / Mwh. That increased cost not only means high electricity bills for consumers. It also means fewer manufacturing and other jobs that rely heavily on power.

I take no issue with the need to keep our air and water clean. I am the father of four. And the climate does appear to be warming. However, this needs to be balanced against the cost of moving to a zealously anti-competitive environment that costs dollars and jobs.

This is what happens when a governmental agency like the EPA is permitted and even encouraged to run roughshod over individuals and business for too long.  There is an inevitable backlash.  When the EPA declared that ponds and small streams on private property [not connected to any larger waterway] are "navigable waters" and subject to EPA regs, that's when I knew the agency had gone rogue.  I have confidence that Scott Pruitt will rein things in and, if he goes too far, there will be a backlash to that.

I bitterly cried for days when W. Bush was elected the first time. I had a strong psychic impression that the world as we knew it would unravel under that man and that life as we had conceived of it would crumble beneath our feet. Then came 9/11 and then the wars and then all the other awful things that his puppeting for Cheney and Rumsfeld brought. I thought he was the worst president ever.

Now I almost long for Bush, something I can't believe I actually just wrote. What we have in The Orange Man is so frightening, so stunningly awful that W. Bush seems like a tame person in comparison. I wake up on the nights I can sleep with knots in my stomach.

When the damage done by the people Orange Man puts into his administration starts to show up in their day-to-day lives, perhaps the sleepy folk who voted against their own best interests will actually notice. I wonder, though, if when they start to feel the pain, they won't blame Obama, two, three, four maybe even eight years from now, and blame the Democrats for all the terrible things that will have befallen them by 2018. That Americans are that profoundly stupid (yes, stupid) is stunning. They are so very easy to manipulate, so gullible and blind.

Clean air and water, fair wages for all, respect for all religions but alignment with none, fair immigration laws, equal rights for all groups, an end to rampant corporate greed.....yes, "elite", liberal values. I hold them strongly and without apology. I'm not alone.

After the election, my 16 year old son broke down in tears. He asked me how and why Donald Trump could have been elected. As I stood there in the kitchen, right before school, still at a loss of how to explain the new, very unexpected situation to him (after being awake all night trying to figure out how to explain things to him and my younger son), he went on to tell me that he felt as though his generation had been given something that they hadn't asked for and didn't want. That they would have to clean up the mess from this for years to come.

After the past month, I see how very right and prescient he was. I am devastated that this is what we our handing the next generation. I'll keep fighting the good fight and teaching the same to my sons, but how I wish Bernie or someone like him would rise above, speak sense to us all (everyone included!) and lead us away from this disaster.

Until the day he died from emphysema, my beloved father blamed the cigarettes that he had stopped smoking twenty five years prior, not the poisonous air that he breathed every day he worked in a Birmingham steel mill.

As a child, the air around my home was often thick with dust and debris from the giant burning stacks of U.S.Steel less than three miles from our neighborhood. Both of my grandfathers, as well as my father worked at "the plant" as they called it. In fact, it would be difficult to find many in our area who were not steel mill employees. Devotion to the company ran deep, and many blamed new EPA regulations on the demise of the steel industry-including my father. Never once did he see the correlation between the disease that took his life and the fact that he bought old clunker cars to drive to work because the air literally ate the paint off. Maya Angelou once said "When I knew better, I did better." Apparently not. Even with the water disaster in Flint, earthquakes from fracking in Oklahoma, and so many potential environmental disasters looming, far too many people refuse to see the long term negative effects this choice can have on our country-indeed the world. Every day I become more frightened for our future. The simple fact that so many knew this would happen and still chose this path for our country is even more frightening.

The EPA did not destroy blue collar jobs. That is a lie repeated endlessly by the oil and gas industry. Your other assertions are baseless. Coal is dying because it is an antiquated source of energy and there are better options now available. Developments in technology and market forces to a large extent have sidelined it. I thought Republicans worshipped the free market? You can't have it both ways. Same reason robots are now eliminating manufacturing jobs left, right and centre. I suppose that's the EPA's fault too?

Hopefully Pruitt will encourage the senate committees to question the theory of human caused global warming. To the liberals this is like religion: accept it or else you are a denier. But those who enjoy thinking and analyzing soon realize that this claim is based on correlations alone, not any modern experiments.

No one is denying that there is some warming of the globe. But that has nothing to do with the cause. To know it and act on it, we need verified experimental proof (not statistical graphs), proof that increasing the CO2 content from 300 to 500 ppm will result in real, measurable warming of the atmosphere.

The numerous reports published by universities and UN sponsored entities do not provide any experiments, only statistical analyses of numerous data. Most people, especially the left wing press with its agenda to promote and their followers, just quote the conclusions and don't bother to drill all the way down into the raw data. Like reading the polls during the campaign: an orgaization does the poll, concludes Hililary will win, and that's what the media goes on.

Hopefully Trump will encouarge Pruitt and the senate to question what the left has been taking as gospel truth.

For those who agree with Mr. Pruitt's selection, I can't help but think that you've never been to New Delhi to witness the smog, to central America to see the trash and pollution in the many of the rivers and stream, or followed a bus in Africa that belches black smoke.  I assume you don't care about the medical reports detailing the higher incidence of asthma in children living next to freeways.  You don't remember American rivers on fire.  You don't remember the haze over L.A..  You haven't noticed the extinction of 100 species per year.  Whether you are naive and conceited, the result will be the same.  How extremely disheartening.

Trump has openly admitted that he likes to get revenge against people who have criticized him.  Thus, courting and dining with Romney, only to most certainly reject him, and meeting with Al Gore and then thumbing his nose and appointing the complete oppposite person of which Gore would approve.  Trump is a very sick guy, with the mind of an acting-out child.  And, of course, Ryan and McConnell remain silent about all this.  If they think they can guide Trump once he's in office, they have another think coming.  Hold on to your seats, folks.  It's going to be a bumpy ride.
